educational-surveillance.title: Educational Surveillance
educational-surveillance.description: Educational surveillance is the surveillance and monitoring of students. Educational surveillance typically assumes two forms: monitoring a student's performance and academic integrity, and monitoring a student's threat to their school and their peers.

health-surveillance.title: Health Surveillance
health-surveillance.description: Health surveillance (also known as public health surveillance) is "the ongoing systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of outcome-specic data essential to the planning, implementation, and evaluation of public health practice, closely integrated with the timely dissemination of these data to those who need to know" (Thacker & Birkhead, 2008).

luxury-surveillance.title: Luxury Surveillance
luxury-surveillance.description: Luxury surveillance is a type of surveillance that "people pay for and whose tracking, monitoring, and quantification features are understood by the user as benefits they are likely to celebrate" (Gilliard & Golumbia, 2021).

mass-surveillance.title: Mass Surveillance
mass-surveillance.description: Mass surveillance is a type of surveillance program that collects vast quantities of data on an entire population. This form of surveillance is often conducted by local and federal governments to fight terrorism, prevent crime, and control a population.

resources.title: Resources
resources.description: - Brennan Center for Justice @ New York University

sousveillance.title: Sousveillance
sousveillance.description: Sousveillance is a recording or observation by a member of the public, rather than a person or organization in a position of power. It typically includes a citizen recording abuse of power or illegal activity by those in positions of power.

surveillance-capitalism.title: Surveillance Capitalism
surveillance-capitalism.description: Surveillance capitalism is the commodification of personal data for the explicit purpose of earning profit. The process typically involves companies leveraging their users' personal data to sell targeted advertisements.

workplace-surveillance.title: Workplace Surveillance
workplace-surveillance.description: Workplace surveillance (also called employee monitoring) is when an organization monitors their employees. The premise for workplace surveillance is to track an employee's performance, avoid legal liability, protect trade secrets, and other similar reasons.
